title: Why the hell does LCS get special treatment?
body:
LCS has some skins banned because they make it harder to play against and the skins somewhat buff your champion, LCS has new champions temporarily banned, LCS has changes halted before those changes went into worlds in season 4.

Where is our special treatment? If it wasnt for the community this game wouldnt even be here right now. You guys need to start treating normal ranked games as if they were the LCS.

I cant wait to not play ranked for 2 weeks on tahm release because nobody knows how to play him but they are going to pick him anyways. Ban him right? But what about sejuani gragas and nunu? just a waste.

replies.body:
Because the LCS has hundreds of thousands of dollars at stake in it's matches, while ranked games do not have any money on the line.

Though they should still block new (or heavily reworked) champion from ranked for 2 weeks anyways, while asking them to ban skins wouldn't happen and would draw huge protest from people who brought it.

Or require Mastery level 3 for newly released/reworked champions to play in ranked in the first two weeks.

Level 3 means you've played at least some games with the champion, and have at least a decent understanding how it works (level 3 = 5+ wins with good ratings).

Mastery rating doesn't reflect skill with a champion though or it would just read win percentage. The biggest issue is that require ring mastery would limit champion pools for ranked: I don't mind playing a restricted pool, but I'm not leveling 16 champs to rank 3 just to play ranked.

Edit: My bad didn't realize you said only required in the first two weeks. As long as you don't need to have mastery points on a champ to play ranked w/ them you can just wait a week or two and save the IP cost when they drop after week one anyway. Still worth noting that mastery still is not reflective of skill so it's setting up for disappointments.
A champion having been purchasable for a while is no better indicator of skill with them, though.

Which is kinda my point. If neither is a good indicator of skill why require the additional time or mastery points to let someone play something in ranked? Just let people play stuff right away, or if you do this to cave to people complaining the make it not a permanent requirement, and we can have the same issue 2 weeks in.
I largely agree. Most of these people ought to realize, if they're as good as they think they are, they'd be higher ranked than the kind of person who plays a champion in ranked for the first time.

Eh, I play a bots game to read the skills and have an idea what the hotbox on skills might be, but all the champs I've picked up recently were learned entirely in ranked. Might be why I haven't made it past low gold but I'm pretty sure it is just that I'm not good enough to carry past low gold.

The thing is "not good enough to carry past low gold" is 100% the same as "I'm a low gold player."

Nothing wrong with that - almost certainly better than I could do - but it is what it is.
Yeah, that's what I was saying though. Stuck in low gold bc I'm a low gold player, not bc I play champs in ranked that I have never played pvp before.

im thinking he meant to say ban NEW champs from ranked unless you're mastery level 3 from them in normals.

that way you can play them in under the 2 week ban but after you've had time to learn them.

When Ekko was released on his second day i entered into ranked and a guy insta locked ekko. He was 3rd pick and we already had an adc and top.

So he said "well i'll just jungle Ekko."

When we asked why the hell he was going jungle with Ekko when he knew we had a top a an ADC his literal words were "because i want to play him and everyone else has him insta locked in normals."

So this jackarse came into my ranked game and locked my jungle with an Ekko because everyone beat him to the draw in normals.

We won, but he didnt do so hot and the rest of the team carried.

Make master 3 on a NEW champ, or go cry in normals I say.
Doesn't help with people not knowing how to play against them though.

Tbh, that's why riot increased the IP price on new champs to 7300 or whatever it is now for the first week, to discourage people from purchasing them right off the bat and waiting to save a boatload of IP by getting them the following week. It is honestly effective, it's not nearly as bad as it used to be tbh. But to be fair, back when this was more problematic, champions were much easier to play. 

I don't think they should ban them from ranked play, honestly they get their best feedback from ranked completion and ranked is the highest level of that outside of LCS. It's why you shouldn't really focus on winrates for the first week or two (unless they're incredibly high, then you know there's a problem) because it takes people forever to learn how to play them, play with them and against them. The truth is, at its highest level, that's how we learn about new champions and their capabilities so quickly. Sure, people will spam them in blind and normals galore but that's nota very accurate assessment because we know a lot of people don't take blind pick or even normal drafts seriously. So ranked data from the first two weeks alone is going to give you a much better perspective on a champions power level, difficulty to play and play with/against assessment than normals will, even though in all probability there's twice as many notmals played than ranked. 

It's a double edged sword but it's a greater good for champion balancing, and after all we are in an ever changing game. Balance changes happen every patch, item changes on occasion and game mechanics even change. Do you want riot to disable all the ap items for a week after this? What about devourer? What about ADCs when the attack move command changed? This is an ever changing game that is patched every two weeks, you need to expect change and you can't exclude new champions from that because then you'd need to start making exceptions for other major changes, which is hilariously stupid to do and it would be hypocritical as hell to say you can't do that with other major changes but you can do it with champions.

In short, get over it. It's a part of the game and I'll give you a piece of advice: ban it. This stops your teammates from picking it if you're worried about them feeding with it. It can be frustrating because other bans might feel more important but it's pretty important to understand winning and losing too and if I think my teammate first timing a new champion in my ranked game increases my chances of losing, well, I dont chance it. I ban it and tell them to eat shit if they complain.

Yes, because equating everything about pro matches and our matches is a core part of the OP's argument... *eye roll*

Look, if you're going to have a sport/esport/game/whatever be played professionally, it does your fanbase good to have the game be the same fundamentally as the one they're playing.  We're talking about one specific example of which patch gets played on in this thread, but it's true in general.  If Riot decided tomorrow to take away all bans from the game, but left them in for pros, it would be equally suspect.  You don't see this type of discrepancy between professional and casual scenes of other sports/esports (well, except that basketball allows travels and flops, but I digress).

If Riot really thought such an environment was healthy for their competitive scene, they could easily have LCS games on the newest patch.  The reason they don't (bugs, poorly balanced releases, worse games when pros don't know how the new champ works) is just as valid for our games.  The fact that I'm not a pro doesn't change any of this.  The chief argument against is just "but I want it noooooow", it's nothing deeper than that.  (And the champion just _happens_ to cost more IP the first week it's out - I'm sure that's just a coincidence, right?).
